p: Climate change can adversely affect food security on global and regional scales. It influences the quality and quantity of agricultural products and, generally, the availability of food [ 34, 35]. Among the consequences of climate change are the increase in temperatures, the decline of rainfall and available water, the erratic fluctuations in rainfall patterns, the changes in flowering patterns of fruit trees, reductions in the number of chill hours and higher risks of late spring frost [ 19, 20, 21]. Climate change and the rise in urbanization have cut back on agricultural lands, and it is necessary to select suitable areas for the cultivation of crops.
